creator: andrei.erdei
title: The Beauty of Math - Conway's Game of Life Art
description: This project visualizes Conway's Game of Life, a cellular automaton, using an Arduino Pro Mini and a 16x16 RGB LED display. It aims to demonstrate the beauty of mathematics through the dynamic patterns generated by the game's simple rules.
steps: Understand the rules of Conway's Game of Life: A dead cell with exactly 3 neighbors becomes alive; a cell with 2 or 3 neighbors survives; otherwise, the cell dies.
Download and adapt Jason Coon's code from Github for software implementation. Modify the code as needed due to memory limitations of the Arduino Pro Mini.
Initialize variables and the 'cell' class. Use functions for random initialization of generation zero, calculating the number of neighbors, and determining the RGB LED order.
Initialize the random number generator and display in the setup function.

In the loop function, every 256 iterations, clear the display, initialize a new generation, display a new color palette, display the cells of generation 0, perform calculations for the new generation, save the calculations, and repeat the cycle.
Connect the Arduino Pro Mini to four 8x8 RGB WS2812 arrays and a 5V 1A power supply following the provided schematic diagram.
If desired, mount the electronics in a box. Add a smoked plexiglas sheet, a piece of paper and plastic frame to blur the LED light effect.
Experiment with different birth and survival rules to observe various patterns and behaviors of the cellular automaton. Choose other rules from Cellular Automata explorer's site.

creator: andrei.erdei
title: The Beauty of Math - Conway's Game of Life Art
materials_required: Microcontroller module with larger RAM (an Arduino Mega or ESP12) (optional for larger display)
Larger power supply: 2.5 - 3A (optional for larger display)
description: This project visualizes Conway's Game of Life and other "Life-Like" worlds on a 16x16 RGB LED display using an Arduino Pro Mini. It adapts existing code and allows for experimentation with different rules and color palettes to create visually appealing patterns.
steps: Understand the rules of Conway's Game of Life: a cell lives, dies, or is born based on the number of its neighbors.
Adapt Jason Coon’s code (available on github) for the Arduino Pro Mini, using color palettes for visual effects.
Initialize variables and a 'cell' class, create functions for random initialization, neighbor calculation, RGB LED order, and color palette selection.
In the setup function, initialize the random number generator and the display.

In the loop function, every 256 iterations, clear the display, initialize a new generation, display a new color palette, display the cells of generation 0, perform calculations for the new generation and save those calculations to start the cycle again.
Connect an Arduino Pro Mini module, four 8x8 RGB WS2812 arrays, and a 5V 1A power supply according to the provided electronic scheme.
Optionally, increase the number of RGB arrays to 16 (32x32 pixel display) and use a microcontroller with larger RAM (Arduino Mega or ESP12) along with a larger power supply (2.5-3A).
Mount the electronics in a box, optionally moving the display away from the smoked plexiglas sheet for a blurred effect.
Upload the software and experiment with different birth and survival rules (Bx/Sy) to observe various patterns.
